title: 114_s3072
content:
The "Countering Terrorist Radicalization Act" includes provisions for countering violent extremism training, assessment, and Department-sponsored clearances. It also focuses on countermessaging terrorist organizations and establishing a Counterterrorism Advisory Board within the Department of Homeland Security. Additionally, there is a prohibition on new funding. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to provide training for personnel at fusion centers to counter violent extremism and identify terrorism threats. Coordination with other Federal agencies is required for the training. The Secretary of Homeland Security will coordinate with heads of other Federal agencies for community outreach on countering violent extremism and related activities. SEC. 102. COUNTERING VIOLENT EXTREMISM ASSESSMENT. The Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with various government representatives, must assess the Department's efforts in supporting countering violent extremism at different levels within 120 days of the Act's enactment. This assessment includes cataloging departmental efforts, reviewing cooperative agreements, and evaluating plans to better assist governments in countering violent extremism. The Secretary of Homeland Security must assess the Department's efforts in supporting countering violent extremism within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The findings will be submitted to Congress within 150 days, including best practices for countering violent extremism at different government levels. SEC. 103. DEPARTMENT-SPONSORED CLEARANCES.

Within 30 days of the Act's enactment, the Secretary of Homeland Security must inform Congress about State, local, tribal, and territorial government employees with security clearances sponsored by the Department. Details include agencies, clearance levels, and assignments to fusion centers.

SEC. 104. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 104. DEFINITIONS.

The term "appropriate congressional committees" refer to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. "Violent extremism" is defined as ideologically motivated international or domestic terrorism. The Secretary of Homeland Security will incorporate public testimonials of former violent extremists into efforts to combat terrorist recruitment. This includes countermessaging foreign terrorist organization communications, community engagement, and coordination with other federal agencies and international partners. The Secretary of Homeland Security will not collect testimonials directly from former violent extremists or their associates, including friends and family. TITLE III--COUNTERTERRORISM ADVISORY BOARD

SEC. 301. DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY COUNTERTERRORISM ADVISORY BOARD. This section adds a new Departmental Coordination on Counterterrorism within the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Department of Homeland Security has established a board to coordinate and integrate intelligence, activities, and policy related to counterterrorism. The board's charter governs its structure and mission, focusing on the current threat environment and aligning counterterrorism activities under the Secretary's guidance. The Secretary appoints a Coordinator for Counterterrorism as the chair of the board, with additional members appointed as needed. The Secretary appoints a Coordinator for Counterterrorism as the chair of the board, with additional members appointed from various agencies within the Department of Homeland Security. The board, chaired by the Coordinator for Counterterrorism appointed by the Secretary, includes members from various agencies within the Department of Homeland Security. It meets regularly to discuss intelligence, coordinate threat mitigation efforts, and make recommendations to the Secretary on terrorism alerts. No additional funds are authorized for this section. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report on the status of the board established under section 210G of the Homeland Security Act within 90 days of enactment. No additional funds are authorized for this Act or its amendments.
